moves.1. Nf3: My intention here was to play the Nimzo-Larsen Attack as White.  Nf3 prevents e5.
moves.1... f6: An unusual response.  It takes away the best square for the N.
moves.2. c4: I transition to the English Opening.
moves.2... d6 3. g3 Bg4 4. Bg2 c6 5. Nc3 g6: I don't understand why Black is creating weaknesses on the Kingside.
moves.6. d4 Be6 7. d5: Also reasonable would have been b3.  White doesn't mind opening up the center since castling can be done quickly, while Black is still far away from it.
moves.7... Bf7 8. O-O e6 9. dxe6 Bxe6 10. b3 N: White has a large lead in development but will need to convert it to a positional advantage.
moves.11... Be7 12. Nd4 Bf7 13. Qd2: This temporarily prevents Nh6, hindering Black's development.
moves.13... a6 14. Rfd1 f5: This makes the Bb2 more powerful by opening the diagonal.
moves.15. e4 fxe4 16. Nxe4 Ngf6 17. Ng5: Also to be considered was Nxd6+, trying to blow the position open immediately.  I decided that with a positional edge I was in no hurry.
moves.17... Bg8 18. Nge6 Bxe6 19. Nxe6 Qb8: This outpost for the N creates a significant positional advantage.
moves.20... Rg8: I think this was played with an eye to preventing Ng7+.
moves.21. Rde1: Doubling up on the Be7 and setting up the kernel of a discovered attack.
moves.21... b6: This allows Bxc6, winning a free pawn.  However, I had larger plans.
moves.22. Nc7+: This kamikaze check wins the exchange.  After Kd8, White wins with Nxa8.
moves.22... Qxc7: Black overlooks the major threat that allows Nc7+ to win the exchange.
moves.23. Qxe7#: An in-your-face checkmate.  Black missed the threat, but hung on quite a while with a difficult position in this game.
